awd_titl_txt: Design of Actibodies For Triggered Recognition
awd_abstract_narration:
1132860 Thomas, Wendy
Recognition proteins such as antibodies have many applications in medicine and biotechnology, but antibodies are not optimized for many of these applications, leading to the recent development of libraries of recognition proteins with novel characteristics, which can be screened to identify proteins that bind a target of interest. In this project, the PI proposes to develop a library of regulated recognition proteins that can be triggered to bind or release on cue.  

Intellectual Merit:  While methods have been developed to engineer regulated proteins in a modular way, these methods have not been applied to the development of diversity libraries in which the specificity can be arbitrarily changed without affecting the allosteric regulation. 

Broader Impacts:  The technology developed in this project should enable improved separation technologies, self-assembled in vitro diagnostic devices, and in vivo molecular imaging or targeted therapeutics.  This project will also increase the transfer of underrepresented students from community colleagues to a top engineering department in a four year university and train six undergraduate students in a research setting.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The project, “Design of Actibodies For Triggered Recognition” resulted in the following outcomes or findings.  Recognition proteins such as antibodies have many applications in medicine and biotechnology that require recognition of specific targets, including separation technologies, molecular diagnostics, and targeted drug delivery. We can identify recognition proteins that bind to targets of interest by immunizing animals with the target or by screening a library of proteins that are similar except for a randomized binding region. Many applications would benefit from triggered recognition, in which the target can be released from the recognition protein on cue, but we have no way to identify proteins that recognize a target of interest and can be released on cue. In this project, we developed a library of recognition proteins that can be triggered to take on two very different shapes. We found that the library can be screened to find recognition proteins for new targets. We also identified a new way to trigger proteins to unbind from their targets, by using a new type of inhibitor called a “parasteric” inhibitor. A parasteric inhibitor attaches to the binding pocket of a protein, and pries it open, causing it to detach quickly from its target. In comparison with a traditional competitive inhibitor, a parasteric inhibitor was more effective at dissolving bacterial biofilms and preventing bacterial adhesion in an animal model of urinary tract infections.

 


Last Modified: 02/10/2016
Modified by: Wendy E Thomas
